metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Percutaneous tracheostomy during the COVID-19 pandemic: sealing the bronchoscope with in-line suction sheath

body_text.text: Editor -Tracheostomy represents a particular challenge during the COVID-19 pandemic. It is an aerosol-generating procedure (AGP) with significant infection risk to surgeon, anaesthetist and theatre staff. Open surgical tracheostomy and percutaneous dilation tracheostomy have differences in terms of aerosol generation. While the choice of technique is beyond the scope of this letter, we would like to emphasise that the surgeon or intensivist performing the tracheostomy should use the technique they are accustomed to reduce risk.
body_text.section: Percutaneous tracheostomy during the COVID-19 pandemic: sealing the bronchoscope with in-line suction sheath

body_text.text: The first percutaneous dilation tracheostomy was performed using multiple sequential dilators over a guide wire. Over the years, two major advances were introduced: use of a single dilator and use of an intubating bronchoscope down the tracheal tube [1] . The latter is, in our view, an indispensable tool to allow safe percutaneous dilation tracheostomy. The bronchoscope allows visualisation of the needle, its correct positioning in the midline and avoidance of the posterior tracheal wall, injury of which can lead to a tracheoesophageal fistula with potentially disastrous consequences [2] . The main drawback to using a bronchoscope in COVID-19 patients is the increase risk of aerosolisation at the insertion point of the bronchoscope at the tracheal tube connection (catheter mount with suction window). We describe a closed, in-line suction system to seal the bronchoscope and reduce the risk to operators and nursing staff.
body_text.section: Percutaneous tracheostomy during the COVID-19 pandemic: sealing the bronchoscope with in-line suction sheath

body_text.text: Our technique utilises the sheath of a 12F closed in-line suction system (Halyard Health, UK). The sheath needs to be circumferentially cut at the suction-valve end of the system ( Fig   1A) with particular attention paid to maintain integrity of the sheath. The suction catheter is removed (Fig 1B and 1C) and a single use videobronchoscope (Ambu® aScope™, Ambu A/S, Ballerup, Denmark) is advanced through the sheath and the one-way valve. The sheath is then tightly taped around the proximal end of the bronchoscope shaft using a Tegaderm™ (3M Healthcare, Germany) film dressing or similar tape (Fig 1D) . Length and mobility of the sheathed segment of the bronchoscope need to take into account the length of the tracheal tube, and this can be tested using an identical tracheal tube away from the patient (Fig 1E) .
body_text.section: Percutaneous tracheostomy during the COVID-19 pandemic: sealing the bronchoscope with in-line suction sheath

body_text.text: The anaesthetist is asked to withdraw the tracheal tube until the cuff sits at or just below the glottis so as to avoid cuff puncture and to reduce duration of the procedure. This should be performed using a videolaryngoscope to protect the anaesthetist from aerosol. The patient should be pre-oxygenated and the ventilator turned off allowing enough time for passive expiration via an open adjustable pressure-limiting (APL) valve. The catheter mount can then be replaced with the mounted bronchoscope and the ventilator connected via the side port.
body_text.section: Percutaneous tracheostomy during the COVID-19 pandemic: sealing the bronchoscope with in-line suction sheath

body_text.text: Ventilation can commence until the start of the percutaneous dilation tracheostomy procedure. To minimise the period during which aerosol might be generated, as well as all the standard equipment tests and checks, we perform a small skin incision prior to needle insertion.
